label: Letter from Gertrude Sanford Legendre, September 29, 1942
description: Letter from Gertrude Legendre to her husband, Sidney Legendre, asking his plans and placement for the rest of the war, updating him on her plans for their daughter, Landine, to attend school in Middleburg, Virginia, and an event she attended at her alma mater, Foxcroft school. Gertrude continues in her letter to describe the house she has rented and ask him questions about his job in Hawaii.

metadata.label: Transcript
metadata.value:
In the Office
No .9
new address. Sept 29th '42
2729 Dunbarton Ave
Dear Sidney,
I got your letter No. 9 to-day dated
Sept 25th - That's pretty good too.
I was so excited talking to you for
three minutes on the telephone I could n't say
anything. We must do it again and next
time I will arrange in advance to talk 6
minutes instead of three. Everything
has to be planned in advance - I was
told I could not say how many letter I
had received. The weather could not be
mentioned or any thing to do with boats
[and] military matters. As a matter
of fact I had received your letter no 8-
when I talked to you. My it was 
wonderful hearing your voice - It made 
you seem near even though you are
6000 miles away-
In this morning's letter you
mention ..."flying and say "this has been 
the most importent part of our work"......
the result is we pick up our mail [and] look
emmediately for one of these big long envelopes."
[End Page 1]
2
How can you be connected with air?.
Have you been trying to change over
to Lester's outfit or what? -
Do you mean you might go off on
a carrier? - [illegible] I thought you
were booked for Hawaii not the
"Swanee" -  what is the dope - Do tell
me. To think of you on a carrier
will be the end- three of you
at sea is unbelievable-
Do please tell me your plans Sidney
I do want to know what is going to 
happen [and] what to expect. I really
think those carriers are nothing but 
death traps - targets -  to be sunk.
They are god awful!! Can't you
stay at Pearl Harbor or what? -
If you are all of a sudden ordered 
to move please please put in a 
long distance call for me [and] talk
to me before you go - Don't forget
please do this. I shall call
you again a week from this Sunday--
Sunday the 11th I think it is. Was that
a good hour to call? - Please let me know
[End Page 2]
3
also give me the hotel telephone number.
How I would love to be [illegible] you on
the beach with those waving palm
trees [and] a big orange moon, a ginger
ley and the soft sound of Hawaiian
music. It makes me sick [and]
my stomach sort of caves in when
I think how agonizing it is to
be apart. At night when I 
come home from work it's really 
hell- I first nearly die- thinking
about you till morning--
The days slip by because I'm
busy so much - but the nights
- god how I would love to be
with you - hug you [and] kiss you
[and] tell you how much I love you.
Miss Charlotte was wonderful!
Landine [and] Melle. are all fixed
up at the Alumnae house in a 
bed room [and] sitting room- for $60- per
week with meals. Cheap I think.
Melle may teach french at the Public
School in Middleburg.
We all lunched with Miss C. [and] she told us
[End Page 3]
4
all about the WAAC's - she had been
out to Des Moine [and] had all the dope-
Foxcroft is "the Baby WAAC's" - they
are all military - have a Col. Butler
training them and are going to graduate
as officer material for the WAAC's - which
is a slick idea. She is always a jump
a head of every body, and she would be
the first to have a girls military school.
I think its tops. It will make them all
disciplined to a tea - do them good, [and]
turn them into good war material for
officers in either WAACs or WAVEs -
Miss Charlotte was most upraised with
the whole set up out there. Found it really
impressive. The Colored Regiment has seperate
barracks, seperate mens etc. it works
perfectly.
I dined with Miss C. [and] the Senior Class
who arrived a day early to get the idea
of "Baby WAACs" [and] it was great fun-
Three of the girls lived on ranches in the west
-- New Mexico, Wyoming [and] Idaho - My
they were mad about it! Said it was
marvelous! Such air, such country!!!
Such scenery!! - Hundreds of acres [and]
hundreds of head of cattle. They looked
full of health too.
[End Page 4]
5
I spent the night [and] motored back to the
office at 7.30 A.M. I drove slowly
[and] it took just 1 1 2 hours - about
5 gallons of of gas. I am going to
try and do it often. It's a swell thing
to do from so many angles.
I move into Helen's house on Dunbarton
Ave. for the month of October - then
1528 31st St. Nov. 1st - for a
year.
Bo arrives here Monday the 4th of Oct.
I have secured "Lucy" who waited on the table
for us at Seal Harbor - to come for the
winter at $100 -- per month to do
everything -  cook, clean, wait etc. She
[and] Rose will be happy to gether [and] I think
it will work out much better than
getting blacks who never stay.
Henry Lowndes tells me our place is
over run with poachers - He is attempting
to hawl in a bunch this week.
I hope I shall get down for a week end [and]
see what goes on on the Plantations.
The weather is chilly [and] even cold now. It's
heaven-!!. Summer seems to be really over.
[End Page 5]
6
What bothers me thought is the steam heat. It's
already been turned on in the building.
The first chilly day the little secretaries
all complained, said they had colds [and] were
cold -  it's awful. I have the radiator
turned off in my office [and] the window
open but when I go out to lunch
the window is closed [and] the heat emmediately
turned on- It's maddening. Those 
two little secretaries of mine never
take a strove of ex ercise - no circulation
they are fat, soft [and] unhealthy--
Hope I don't look like that when I
get through a year of this.
I walk down [and] back or bycicle - but it's
such a short way - I do ex ercises in
my room but I don't know how much
good they do--
Happy Birthday to fat face! I am not
going to cable because he would get it after
the war--
Lots [and] lots of love my darling--
[and] keep on writing all the new, everything
you do - all details - I love it -
Gertie
[End Page 6]
P.S. 
What I don't understand is what sort
of a job you have - besides being
desk movers - are you Big Shots?
Are you directly [illegible] to the
General Staff? Are you right 
under Nimitz? - you sound
importent - but I do hope
you don't get into sea duty
[and] real danger- of course you
know best what you want
to do - but - god I do hope
for the best. If your job it
interesting - I am so glad for you-
you said it was [and] I am wondering
why you wish to think of 
doing something else - or is
all this air idea unavoidable.
You say Morris is so efficient. How about
yourself. I bet you do all the work-
Do go to the Ostiopath about your
back. Moving desks doesn't help		S.S.!
it I assume. Take care of yourself my darling
How are your feet [and] your ears?
[End Page 7]
